keyTakeAways: The Nobel Prizes are among the most prestigious international awards, established by Alfred Nobel's will in 1895 to recognize individuals who have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.
The prizes are awarded annually across six categories: physics, chemistry, medicine, literature, peace, and economics, each administered by a specific institution.

The 2025 medicine prize was awarded to Mary Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell, and Shimon Sakaguchi for their discoveries concerning peripheral immune tolerance, which have enabled new research and treatments for cancer and autoimmune diseases.
The 2024 medicine prize went to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun for discovering microRNAs, which regulate gene expression.
The 2024 physics prize was awarded to John Hopfield and Geoffrey Hinton for foundational work in artificial neural networks and machine learning.
The 2024 chemistry prize was shared by David Baker, Demis Hassabis, and John Jumper for breakthroughs in protein structure prediction, notably through AlphaFold.
The 2024 literature prize was awarded to South Korean author Han Kang for her powerful exploration of violence and human fragility.
The 2024 peace prize went to Nihon Hidankyo, recognizing its campaign against nuclear weapons and preservation of survivor testimonies.
The 2024 economics prize was shared by Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James Robinson for their work on how inclusive institutions shape long-term economic growth.
The nomination process is confidential, with experts, academics, and past winners submitting nominations by January 31 each year, and decisions kept secret for 50 years.
The Nobel Prize announcements are a globally watched event, broadcast worldwide and followed by major ceremonies in Stockholm and Oslo.

Academic freedom is under concern due to political interference, particularly under the Trump administration, with officials like Ylva Engstrom from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences warning of long-term damage to scientific integrity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The 2025 Nobel Prizes officially began with the announcement of the medicine prize to Mary Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell, and Shimon Sakaguchi for their discoveries in peripheral immune tolerance, which have advanced treatments for cancer and autoimmune diseases. The full announcement schedule spans from October 6 to October 13, covering medicine, physics, chemistry, literature, peace, and economics. The article highlights past laureates such as Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun (medicine), John Hopfield and Geoffrey Hinton (physics), David Baker, Demis Hassabis, and John Jumper (chemistry), Han Kang (literature), and Nihon Hidankyo (peace), as well as Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James Robinson (economic sciences). The article also addresses public debate surrounding Donald Trump’s claims of deserving the 2025 Peace Prize, emphasizing that the Norwegian Nobel Committee typically values durable peace efforts over political self-promotion. Experts warn that political interference, particularly from the Trump administration, threatens academic freedom, and institutions stress the importance of maintaining scientific independence and integrity.
